factoid: She said 'O God! I am lost!' to herself.
She said 'How could I let him?' to herself.
She sat for a long time hiding her flushed face in her hands.
She tried to realize what had happened to her.
She was unable to understand what had happened.
She was unable to understand what she felt.
Everything seemed dark, obscure, and terrible.
The theater was enormous and illuminated.
Duport was bare-legged and wore a tinsel-decorated jacket.
Duport jumped about to music on wet boards.
Young girls and old men were present in the theater.
Hélène was nearly naked and had a proud, calm smile.
Hélène cried 'bravo!' rapturously.
In the presence of Hélène everything seemed clear and simple.
Now, alone, she found it incomprehensible.
She thought 'What is it? What was that terror I felt of him? What is this gnawing of conscience I am feeling now?'.
Only the old countess could hear Natásha's feelings at night in bed.
Natásha knew that Sónya would not understand or would be horrified by her confession.
Natásha tried to solve what was torturing her by herself.
She asked herself 'Am I spoiled for Andrew’s love or not?'.
She replied 'What a fool I am to ask that!'.
She said 'What did happen to me? Nothing!'.
She said 'I have done nothing.'.
She said 'I didn’t lead him on at all.'.
She said 'Nobody will know and I shall never see him again.'.
She said 'So it is plain that nothing has happened and there is nothing to repent of, and Andrew can love me still.'.
She wondered why Andrew still loves her.
She wondered why Andrew isn't here.
She quieted herself for a moment.
She had an instinct telling her that the former purity of her love for Prince Andrew had perished.
She imagined her conversation with Kurágin.
She saw the face, gestures, and tender smile of Kurágin when he pressed her arm.
Anatole Kurágin was staying in Moscow.
Anatole Kurágin’s father had sent him away from Petersburg.
Anatole Kurágin had been spending twenty thousand rubles a year in cash in Petersburg.
Anatole Kurágin had been running up debts for more than twenty thousand rubles.
Anatole Kurágin’s creditors demanded money from his father.
Anatole Kurágin’s father announced he would pay half his debts for the last time.
The payment was conditional on Anatole Kurágin going to Moscow as adjutant to the commander in chief.
Anatole Kurágin’s father procured the post of adjutant for him.
Anatole Kurágin’s father would try to make a good match for him in Moscow.
Anatole Kurágin’s father indicated Princess Mary to him.
Anatole Kurágin’s father indicated Julie Karágina to him.
Anatole Kurágin consented to go to Moscow.
Anatole Kurágin went to Moscow.
Anatole Kurágin put up at Pierre’s house.
Pierre received Anatole Kurágin unwillingly at first.
Pierre got used to Anatole Kurágin after a while.
Pierre sometimes accompanied Anatole Kurágin on his carousals.
Pierre gave Anatole Kurágin money under the guise of loans.
Shinshín remarked that Anatole Kurágin turned the heads of Moscow ladies.
Anatole Kurágin slighted Moscow ladies.
Anatole Kurágin preferred gypsy girls and French actresses.
Anatole Kurágin was said to have intimate relations with Mademoiselle George.
Anatole Kurágin never missed a carousal at Danílov’s.
Anatole Kurágin never missed other Moscow revelers’ carousals.
Anatole Kurágin drank whole nights through.
Anatole Kurágin outvied everyone else at carousals.
Anatole Kurágin attended all balls and parties of the best society.
There was talk of Anatole Kurágin's intrigues with some ladies.
Anatole Kurágin flirted with a few ladies at the balls.
Anatole Kurágin did not run after unmarried girls.
Anatole Kurágin did not run after rich heiresses.
The rich heiresses were most of them plain.
Anatole Kurágin had married two years before.
The marriage was known only to his most intimate friends.
Anatole Kurágin was with his regiment in Poland when a Polish landowner forced him to marry his daughter.
Anatole Kurágin abandoned his wife soon after the marriage.
Anatole Kurágin sent a payment to his father-in-law.
Anatole Kurágin arranged to pass himself off as a bachelor.
